The new Phipps Psychiatric Clinic
of the Hopkins Hospital, endowed
through the munificence of Henry
Phipps, the Pittsburgh - millionaire,
will be formally opened, with impressive services, on Wednesday,
April 16. Sir William Osier, regius
professor of medicine at Oxford
University and honorary professor
of medicine at the Hopkins Medical
School, will deliver the principal address. The exercises will last three
days, and will be attended by men
prominent in the medical and scientific circles, and from all parts of
the United States.
The exercises will begin at 3
P. M. on April 16 with an invocation delivered by Rufus M. Jones
of Haverford College. This will
be followed by a few introductory
remarks by Dr. William H. Welch,
chairman of the Administrative
Board of the faculty, and by some
words of appreciation from Judge.
Henry D. Harlan, president of the
Board of Trustees. Dr. Osier will

Dr. Walter Hines Page, fellow of
Johns Hopkins, editor of World's
Work and member of the firm of
Doubleday, Page
Co., publishers,
accepted. last week the ambassadorship to the Court of St. James, tendered him by President Wilson. He
will sail for London this week.
Dr. Page is a North Carolinan,
and is spoken of as "one of those fine
old Southern gentlemen" in New
York, where his business interests
make it necessary for him to live.
He is fifty-eight years of age, has
three sons who are all graduates of
Harvard, and a daughter, a student
in the last year at Bryn Mawr.
The new representative of this
country in Great Britain has been
.one of the most prominent members
of the New York Johns Hopkins
Alumni Association, and it will be
remembered that following his address before the annual banquet of
that society last month at the Lafayette House, he was strongly

MISSION STUDY CLASSES FORMED
To Be Under the Leadership of Alexander K. Barton,'14, and
C. Guyer Kelly,'08.

Two mission study classes were
formed last week. One under the
leadership of Alexander Barton will
study India and its present problems and will be primarily for members of the sophomore class. The
text-book will be "The Desire of
India," by S. K. Datta, a native of
India. The other will be led by
C. Guyer Kelly, A. B. 'oS, who,
during the past two years, has
traveled extensively in Asia and
Africa with Prof. Harlan P. Beach
of Yale University. The book to
be used as a text in this course will
he Dr. Zwerner's "The Unoccupied
Mission Fields of Asia and Africa."
This class will be for upperclassmen and graduate students.

Cheering.

Track Needs.

lopkins this year has a track and
fieil schedule that would not be
undertaken by three-fourths of the
larger institutions in this country.
was only arranged on the faith
()f that "Hopkins spirit," which, in •
its highest development, seeks for
"new fields to conquer."
To carry the team through this
spring season, the largest possible
squad obtainable is necessary. The
reason for this is that every man is
needed and can be used, no matter
how humble his efforts may be in
his own estimation. A decade ago
the track squad, with a most unpretentious schedule, numbered from
forty to fifty men. Surely with our
present facilities and engagements
we should go over this mark.
It is the desire of the coaches and
wanagement that every Hopkins
student—graduate, medical, special,
undergraduate—who has the best
interests of Hopkins at heart—come
out. Not next week, but now. The
first meeting takes Place Friday,
April ii. If that meet were held
today the result would be disastrous
for Hopkins. One week later comes
the Navy. Can we "get them" this
year? That question can only be
answered of you—"Mr. Hopkins
Man."
Hopkins needs you, needs your
active participation in the practices,
rather than your good wishes expressed in an easy chair with a
cigarette in your mouth. Don't
think it over, "do it now," and bring
another man out with you. Also
there is no place for a "k-nocker" on
the squad.
Practice is held every day for
everyone (unless personally excused) at Homewood at 5 P. M.,
rain or shine. The track is in shape.
It was built for running purposes,
and not to admire. It also gives
us pleasure to announce that Mr.
Kistler has very generously volunteered to assist in the field coaching.
(Signed) THE BOARD OP COACHES,
H. E. CATLIN, Capt.,
P. 0. CARTER, 21Ingr.,
GEO. DORSET, Asst. Aingr.

standing- of Bergson's philosophy

who hold that time is nothing—past

present time passing, and therefore
nothing, and future time not here,
and therefore nothing—maintains
that time as a 'fundamental philosophical entity.

Homewood Contracts In.

The Board of Trustees at its regular monthly meeting last Monday
opened estimates from six contractors for the building of Gilman Hall,
the first of the new buildings to be
erected on the Homewood tract.
After the meeting none of the
trustees felt inclined to discuss the
contracts, but one said that it would
take some time to go over them in
detail to make comparisons and select the best of the bids. The detail
pall of this work will be done by
the Homewciod Committee, which is
composed of trustees, and it is probable that a sub-committee will be.
appointed to make a final inspection
of the estimates.
Just how much time will be required to accomplish this study of
the contracts could not be estimated
by one of the Board.
"We are anxious," he said, "to
open Gilnian Hall as soon as possible, but the work must not be
hastened. Naturally, the contracts.
vary in detail, and it will be necessary to select the one which, in our
judgment, will cause the best Gilman Hall to be erected. This will
take some time, but we shall do it
as speedily as possible."

Death of Dr. Stewart.

Dr. Hugh Angus Stewart, formerly associated with the Johns Hopkins Hospital and Medical School,
died Saturday, March 29, at the Willard Park Hospital in New York.
Until his death he was assistant professor of pathology at the College of
Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia
University. Dr. Stewart was born
in Blair Athol, Scotland, on July
28, 1882, and received his degree
from the University of Edinburgh
in 1904. He became the resident
physician of the Royal Infirmary in
Edinburgh, and was made a member
of the Department of Public Health
of •London and of Edinburgh. In
1907 he came to this country to be
assistant resident physician at the
Hopkins Hospital, and during the
following year he was an instructor
in pathology at the Medical School.
Dr. Stewart has done much work
during his short life, and at the time
of his death had almost completed
a very valuable series of experiments in the treatment of certain
diseases.

Professors Honored.

Dr. William H. Welch, professor
of pathology, and Dr. Llewellys F.
Barker, professor of medicine at the
Hopkins Medical School, have been
elected members of the Board of
Scientific Directors of the Eugenics
Record Office, established on Long
Island in 1910, and maintained by
Mrs. E. H. Harriman, John D.
Rockefeller and others. The aim of
the Eugenics Record Office :is,
among other things, to promote researches in eugenics that shall be of
utility to the human race. Methods
of increasing and maintaining a
good race of people, and of restricting the defective classes are to be
studied. The effects of heredity and
inheritance of particular traits, especially among immigrants, are to
be thoroughly investigated. By promoting such research work, the office may be of immense good to our
country.

THE NEWS—LETTER, APRIL 7, 1913.

THIRD ORATORICAL CONTEST
Mr. Calvert Magruder, of St. John's College, and Mr. D. L. Waldron; of
Georgetown, the Winners.

Last Friday evening the third
Maryland Intercollegiate Contest in
Oratory was held in McCoy Hall.
Dr. John M. Vincent, professor of
European history, presided. The
judges of the contest were: Rev.
H. B. McCormick, Mr. Thomas H.
Bowles, Mr. J. Barry Mahool, Mr.
William H. Morriss and Judge Alfred S. Niles. Mr. F. C. Kuehn,
'II, the musician of the evening,
played several pieces of classical
music really exquisitely. Everyone
present was delighted with the orations made by the contestants—
which were of an unusually high
order, even in comparison with
those delivered at the previous contests in oratory. The only disappointing feature of the evening, to
Hopkins men at any rate, was that
J. C. Uhler, Hopkins' representative
in the contest, was not awarded one
of the prizes by the judges. He
spoke in a simple and unaffected
manner in his clear, musical voice,
his chief asset. He failed, however,
to deduce from his long list of well
selected facts any really important
general principles.
The first speaker, Mr. D. L. Waldron, of Georgetown University, won
the second prize. He was clearly
the greatest orator of the evening,
but he allowed himself to be carried
away from the dignified and eloquent expression of his thoughts
into the expression of ideas which
probably were not clear to the
speaker, and certainly not so to the
audience.
The second speaker, Mr. W. L.
Baldwin, of Washington College,
often stepped into the field of the
melo-dramatic, from the safer field
of the oratorical. His figures of
speech were over trite, and too many
of his sentences were climactic.
The third speaker, Mr. Calvert
Magruder, representative of St.
St. John's College, was awarded the
first prize. His voice had no real
richness, but his thoughts were expressed.clearly and logically, though
he was not as inspiring as Many of
the other speakers. It is doubtful
if the audience appreciated all his
sly sallies of humor.
Loyola College was represented
by G. B. Loden. His voice was
very high pitched, and he was impassioned through the whole of his
speech. The speech itself gave the
impression that the speaker /Possessed . some real mental power.
Many of his sentences were epigramatic, and all were most fittingly
expressed.
The details of the contest were
arranged by a committee of the Grotius Society, of which H. W. Richmond was chairman. The prizes,
one of $75, and one of $30, were
given by the Maryland Peace Society.
The intercollegiate tennis title ,I
was won last year by Princeton. ,

Third Cotillon.

The third and last dance of the
Cotillon Club for the season 1912-13
was held on last Saturday night,
April 5, in McCoy Hall. Not only
was there a larger attendance than
usual, but the whole crowd seemed
especially gay and lively, owing to
the double victoyy in the afternoon
over Western Maryland and Cornell. The class . flags were seen
again, cards were confused, everybody came late, and the dance fully
conformed to all traditions, the only
difference being that it was, if anything, more successful than most of
the others.
The 1912-13 season has marked
several changes in the Cotillon
Club's dances. Chief of these is
the selection of a non-fraternity
member for the Board, which, up
until this year, has consisted wholly
of representatives from the various
fraternities. Another change is the
• separation of the office of secretarytreasurer into the two offices of
secretary and treasurer; although
this change seems to be due merely
to the fact that there were three
senior members of the Board this
year, and it was thought best to
divide the honots fairly.
More noticeable to visitors is the
introduction of a receiving line at
the beginning of each dance. This
feature is a great improvement and
should be continued; it gives an opportunity for the girls to meet the
chaperons without the sometimes
awkward stopping in the middle of
a dance.
On the whole, the season has been
very successful, and it indicates that
the Cotillon Club is, and will continue to be, in a flourishing condition.

Half-Price Tickets to Be Given Schoolboys by the J. H. U. Athletic
Association.

Hopkins Tennis Team Will Play Washingtonians at Homewood—Courts Were
Thrown Open Friday Last.

The Johns Hopkins Athletic Association has just inaugurated a
system of tickets, allowing boys of
Baltimore secondary schools to see
all Hopkins athletic games at half
price. Six hundred and fifty of
these tickets were sent last week to
the City College and they were also
distributed in like quantities at all
the other preparatory schools of the
city. In addition, bona fide students
at such schools can secure additional
tickets for their own use by applying at the office of Graduate Manager Burgan.
The ticket is blue and reads as
follows on the face:

The Hopkins tennis team will begin its season next Saturday at 2
P. M. on the FIomewood courts.
Georgetown University will be the
opponents. After the match, Hopkins will entertain the Georgetown
team at supper. It is expected that
Georgetown will present a strong
line-up. Last year one of their
team was Norris McLean, the well
known intercity player, in 1910 joint
holder with "Babe" Fisher of the
West Virginia Doubles Championship, and the same year runner-up
in the District of Columbia singles
tournament. It is thought that McLean will play for Georgetown
again.
Brousseau, their captain in 1911,
who is also an excellent player, has
graduated.
Although against men of this
calibre in 1911, Hopkins tied
Georgetown with the score 3 to 3.
Darkness prevented the conclusion
of the match.
Of the five men who played that
(lay—Belt, Bacon, Corner, Hatch
and Hammond—three, Bacon, Corner and Hammond, are still at the
University.
Last Friday one court was thrown
open for use, and Monday the rest
were ready. Captain Hammond has
been busy getting all candidates out.
It is unfortunate that the team
will have so little practice before
the first match; however, with a
week's work, the men should be in
fair shape.
The Tennis Committee has received challenges for the class teams
from Polytechnic and City College.
The freshman class has chosen
Webb-Peploe to look into the matter of getting up a team, and the
sophomores have elected a captainmanager. Nineteen fourteen has a
standing challenge open to all of
the classes, including the seniors.

when the college team will not be
using the courts, are April 19 and

Two mission study classes were
formed last week. One under the
leadership of Alexander Barton will
study India and its present problems and will be primarily for members of the sophomore class. The
text-book will be "The Desire of
India," by S. K. Datta, a native of
India. The other will be led by
C. Guyer Kelly, A. B. 'oS, who,
during the past two years, has
traveled extensively in Asia and
Africa with Prof. Harlan P. Beach
of Yale University. The book to
be used as a text in this course will
he Dr. Zwerner's "The Unoccupied
Mission Fields of Asia and Africa."
This class will be for upperclassmen and graduate students.

Track Needs.

lopkins this year has a track and
fieil schedule that would not be
undertaken by three-fourths of the
larger institutions in this country.
was only arranged on the faith
()f that "Hopkins spirit," which, in •
its highest development, seeks for
"new fields to conquer."
To carry the team through this
spring season, the largest possible
squad obtainable is necessary. The
reason for this is that every man is
needed and can be used, no matter
how humble his efforts may be in
his own estimation. A decade ago
the track squad, with a most unpretentious schedule, numbered from
forty to fifty men. Surely with our
present facilities and engagements
we should go over this mark.
It is the desire of the coaches and
wanagement that every Hopkins
student—graduate, medical, special,
undergraduate—who has the best
interests of Hopkins at heart—come
out. Not next week, but now. The
first meeting takes Place Friday,
April ii. If that meet were held
today the result would be disastrous
for Hopkins. One week later comes
the Navy. Can we "get them" this
year? That question can only be
answered of you—"Mr. Hopkins
Man."
Hopkins needs you, needs your
active participation in the practices,
rather than your good wishes expressed in an easy chair with a
cigarette in your mouth. Don't
think it over, "do it now," and bring
another man out with you. Also
there is no place for a "k-nocker" on
the squad.
Practice is held every day for
everyone (unless personally excused) at Homewood at 5 P. M.,
rain or shine. The track is in shape.
It was built for running purposes,
and not to admire. It also gives
us pleasure to announce that Mr.
Kistler has very generously volunteered to assist in the field coaching.
(Signed) THE BOARD OP COACHES,
H. E. CATLIN, Capt.,
P. 0. CARTER, 21Ingr.,
GEO. DORSET, Asst. Aingr.

Homewood Contracts In.

The Board of Trustees at its regular monthly meeting last Monday
opened estimates from six contractors for the building of Gilman Hall,
the first of the new buildings to be
erected on the Homewood tract.
After the meeting none of the
trustees felt inclined to discuss the
contracts, but one said that it would
take some time to go over them in
detail to make comparisons and select the best of the bids. The detail
pall of this work will be done by
the Homewciod Committee, which is
composed of trustees, and it is probable that a sub-committee will be.
appointed to make a final inspection
of the estimates.
Just how much time will be required to accomplish this study of
the contracts could not be estimated
by one of the Board.
"We are anxious," he said, "to
open Gilnian Hall as soon as possible, but the work must not be
hastened. Naturally, the contracts.
vary in detail, and it will be necessary to select the one which, in our
judgment, will cause the best Gilman Hall to be erected. This will
take some time, but we shall do it
as speedily as possible."

Death of Dr. Stewart.

Dr. Hugh Angus Stewart, formerly associated with the Johns Hopkins Hospital and Medical School,
died Saturday, March 29, at the Willard Park Hospital in New York.
Until his death he was assistant professor of pathology at the College of
Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia
University. Dr. Stewart was born
in Blair Athol, Scotland, on July
28, 1882, and received his degree
from the University of Edinburgh
in 1904. He became the resident
physician of the Royal Infirmary in
Edinburgh, and was made a member
of the Department of Public Health
of •London and of Edinburgh. In
1907 he came to this country to be
assistant resident physician at the
Hopkins Hospital, and during the
following year he was an instructor
in pathology at the Medical School.
Dr. Stewart has done much work
during his short life, and at the time
of his death had almost completed
a very valuable series of experiments in the treatment of certain
diseases.

Professors Honored.

Dr. William H. Welch, professor
of pathology, and Dr. Llewellys F.
Barker, professor of medicine at the
Hopkins Medical School, have been
elected members of the Board of
Scientific Directors of the Eugenics
Record Office, established on Long
Island in 1910, and maintained by
Mrs. E. H. Harriman, John D.
Rockefeller and others. The aim of
the Eugenics Record Office :is,
among other things, to promote researches in eugenics that shall be of
utility to the human race. Methods
of increasing and maintaining a
good race of people, and of restricting the defective classes are to be
studied. The effects of heredity and
inheritance of particular traits, especially among immigrants, are to
be thoroughly investigated. By promoting such research work, the office may be of immense good to our
country.

THE NEWS—LETTER, APRIL 7, 1913.

THIRD ORATORICAL CONTEST
Mr. Calvert Magruder, of St. John's College, and Mr. D. L. Waldron; of
Georgetown, the Winners.

Last Friday evening the third
Maryland Intercollegiate Contest in
Oratory was held in McCoy Hall.
Dr. John M. Vincent, professor of
European history, presided. The
judges of the contest were: Rev.
H. B. McCormick, Mr. Thomas H.
Bowles, Mr. J. Barry Mahool, Mr.
William H. Morriss and Judge Alfred S. Niles. Mr. F. C. Kuehn,
'II, the musician of the evening,
played several pieces of classical
music really exquisitely. Everyone
present was delighted with the orations made by the contestants—
which were of an unusually high
order, even in comparison with
those delivered at the previous contests in oratory. The only disappointing feature of the evening, to
Hopkins men at any rate, was that
J. C. Uhler, Hopkins' representative
in the contest, was not awarded one
of the prizes by the judges. He
spoke in a simple and unaffected
manner in his clear, musical voice,
his chief asset. He failed, however,
to deduce from his long list of well
selected facts any really important
general principles.
The first speaker, Mr. D. L. Waldron, of Georgetown University, won
the second prize. He was clearly
the greatest orator of the evening,
but he allowed himself to be carried
away from the dignified and eloquent expression of his thoughts
into the expression of ideas which
probably were not clear to the
speaker, and certainly not so to the
audience.
The second speaker, Mr. W. L.
Baldwin, of Washington College,
often stepped into the field of the
melo-dramatic, from the safer field
of the oratorical. His figures of
speech were over trite, and too many
of his sentences were climactic.
The third speaker, Mr. Calvert
Magruder, representative of St.
St. John's College, was awarded the
first prize. His voice had no real
richness, but his thoughts were expressed.clearly and logically, though
he was not as inspiring as Many of
the other speakers. It is doubtful
if the audience appreciated all his
sly sallies of humor.
Loyola College was represented
by G. B. Loden. His voice was
very high pitched, and he was impassioned through the whole of his
speech. The speech itself gave the
impression that the speaker /Possessed . some real mental power.
Many of his sentences were epigramatic, and all were most fittingly
expressed.
The details of the contest were
arranged by a committee of the Grotius Society, of which H. W. Richmond was chairman. The prizes,
one of $75, and one of $30, were
given by the Maryland Peace Society.
The intercollegiate tennis title ,I
was won last year by Princeton. ,

Third Cotillon.

The third and last dance of the
Cotillon Club for the season 1912-13
was held on last Saturday night,
April 5, in McCoy Hall. Not only
was there a larger attendance than
usual, but the whole crowd seemed
especially gay and lively, owing to
the double victoyy in the afternoon
over Western Maryland and Cornell. The class . flags were seen
again, cards were confused, everybody came late, and the dance fully
conformed to all traditions, the only
difference being that it was, if anything, more successful than most of
the others.
The 1912-13 season has marked
several changes in the Cotillon
Club's dances. Chief of these is
the selection of a non-fraternity
member for the Board, which, up
until this year, has consisted wholly
of representatives from the various
fraternities. Another change is the
• separation of the office of secretarytreasurer into the two offices of
secretary and treasurer; although
this change seems to be due merely
to the fact that there were three
senior members of the Board this
year, and it was thought best to
divide the honots fairly.
More noticeable to visitors is the
introduction of a receiving line at
the beginning of each dance. This
feature is a great improvement and
should be continued; it gives an opportunity for the girls to meet the
chaperons without the sometimes
awkward stopping in the middle of
a dance.
On the whole, the season has been
very successful, and it indicates that
the Cotillon Club is, and will continue to be, in a flourishing condition.

Half-Price Tickets to Be Given Schoolboys by the J. H. U. Athletic
Association.

Hopkins Tennis Team Will Play Washingtonians at Homewood—Courts Were
Thrown Open Friday Last.

The Johns Hopkins Athletic Association has just inaugurated a
system of tickets, allowing boys of
Baltimore secondary schools to see
all Hopkins athletic games at half
price. Six hundred and fifty of
these tickets were sent last week to
the City College and they were also
distributed in like quantities at all
the other preparatory schools of the
city. In addition, bona fide students
at such schools can secure additional
tickets for their own use by applying at the office of Graduate Manager Burgan.
The ticket is blue and reads as
follows on the face:

The Hopkins tennis team will begin its season next Saturday at 2
P. M. on the FIomewood courts.
Georgetown University will be the
opponents. After the match, Hopkins will entertain the Georgetown
team at supper. It is expected that
Georgetown will present a strong
line-up. Last year one of their
team was Norris McLean, the well
known intercity player, in 1910 joint
holder with "Babe" Fisher of the
West Virginia Doubles Championship, and the same year runner-up
in the District of Columbia singles
tournament. It is thought that McLean will play for Georgetown
again.
Brousseau, their captain in 1911,
who is also an excellent player, has
graduated.
Although against men of this
calibre in 1911, Hopkins tied
Georgetown with the score 3 to 3.
Darkness prevented the conclusion
of the match.
Of the five men who played that
(lay—Belt, Bacon, Corner, Hatch
and Hammond—three, Bacon, Corner and Hammond, are still at the
University.
Last Friday one court was thrown
open for use, and Monday the rest
were ready. Captain Hammond has
been busy getting all candidates out.
It is unfortunate that the team
will have so little practice before
the first match; however, with a
week's work, the men should be in
fair shape.
The Tennis Committee has received challenges for the class teams
from Polytechnic and City College.
The freshman class has chosen
Webb-Peploe to look into the matter of getting up a team, and the
sophomores have elected a captainmanager. Nineteen fourteen has a
standing challenge open to all of
the classes, including the seniors.

when the college team will not be
using the courts, are April 19 and
